title: Case Study: A 35-Year-Old Male with a Finger Fracture
clinical_history: A 35-year-old right-handed male, who works as a carpenter, presents with a complaint of pain and swelling in his left index finger. He reports that he injured his finger while working on a construction site 3 days ago. He was using a hammer when he accidentally hit his finger instead of the nail. He noticed immediate pain, swelling, and difficulty moving the finger. He has been experiencing increased pain and stiffness since the injury.
aggrevating_factors: Flexion, extension, and rotation of the left index finger; gripping objects; and direct pressure on the finger
picture: The patient has a visibly swollen and bruised left index finger, which is held in a slightly flexed position.
easing_factors: Rest; ice application; and elevation of the hand
past_history: The patient has a history of a distal radius fracture in his right wrist 5 years ago, which was managed conservatively. He has also had occasional episodes of thumb pain and stiffness, which he attributes to overuse from work-related activities.
medical_history: Generally healthy; takes occasional acetaminophen for pain relief
medications: Acetaminophen 1000mg every 4-6 hours as needed for pain
personal_history: Married with two children; works full-time as a carpenter; enjoys playing guitar and hiking in his free time
imaging: X-ray of the left index finger shows a non-displaced fracture of the proximal phalanx
